title: Tuesday, 26th April, 2016

11:04 am
PM

Talking about the end of 'policy panic' in Saudi

PM

Vision 2030 endorsed by the Cabinet, announced by the King and briefly outlined in his first TV interview by the Deputy Crown Prince (DCP) today lays out a strategy of self-help and reform in an attempt to address domestic economic and social vulnerabilities (excluding succession). The unprecedented boldness of the vision mirrors the unprecedented centralisation of power and international public relations offensive (e.g. lengthy press interviews) under the DCP. At first glance, Vision 2030 appears to us aspirational but it clearly sets the strategic tone for this regime. And it is premised on fiscal efficiency rather than fiscal expansion. As such, it signals that the era of policy panic, in the face of the “Arab Spring” first, the change in US foreign policy priorities second and the oil price collapse third, has ended. But the question remains open as to whether a revolution in the economy (in terms of composition and governance) and societal behaviour can be managed in under 15 years and within the confines of the political frameworks (deference to clerics, cohesion of the broader ruling family) underpinning the absolutist, monarchic system, particularly after the 2008-2014 era of public spending hikes. A long-term strategy, or vision, is now in place; whether it is implemented effectively and is ultimately successful remains to be seen.

PM

Equities Cheap Relative to History, Reflecting Converging Risks

11:05 am
PM

We have extensively discussed the structural investment positives and risks of Saudi equities and sector preferences therein before and there is no change to those views. We view the market as cheap relative to history but a number of long-standing, structural risks are simultaneously manifesting themselves on a shorter-term horizon (low oil price, low public sector productivity, high subsidy and welfare dependency, high male youth and female unemployment, disruptions to domestic social and political norms of behaviour, worsening regional insecurity, strains on historic international alliances and rising defence costs). Despite the recent rally, the Tadawul All-Share is still down 26% in US$ total return terms in the last year, and is valued on trailing price/book of 1.6x (vs a 5-year range of 1.3x to 2.7x) and trailing price/ earnings of 16x (vs a 5-year range of (13x to 22x). We continue to prefer sectors relatively less at risk of project spending cuts, quasi-control of socially-sensitive prices and fees and closer to citizen welfare: healthcare, consumer discretionary (where consumer confidence may start to recover with this announcement) and petrochemicals (which are large employers of white-collar citizens and have high levels of government ownership, two factors which may delay a revision of their subsidised gas feedstock price) over consumer staples, banks, construction and cement.

PM

Targets in Vision 2030 which stand out include the (1) elimination of the dependence on oil (currently 90% of government spending is dependent on oil); (2) increase in share of GDP from non-oil exports from 16% to 50%; (3) reduction in overall unemployment from 12% to 7% while raising female labour force participation from 22% to 30%. Vision 2030 also outlines potential sources of non-oil diversification from investment returns, minerals exploitation, defence equipment, stickier expatriates and tourism. In this regard, highlights include: (1) confirmation of an IPO of Aramco (under a 5% stake with further subsidiary IPOs to follow); (2) expansion of the Public Investment Fund to US$2tn (by injecting existing government financial, real estate and industrial assets and Aramco IPO proceeds); (3) localisation of 50% of military purchases; (4) a “green card” system for long-term expatriate residents; and (5) development of an Islamic Museum (which might be a shot across the bows of those in the ideological spectrum who shun preservation of artefacts) and a broadening of the tourist offering beyond religious pilgrimage. A more detailed National Transformation Plan is a part of Vision 2030 and is likely to be released in May or June.

PM

Standard Chartered PLC (STAN:LSE): Last: 571.90, up 51.3 (+9.85%), High: 575.20, Low: 511.90, Volume: 8.12m

BE

BE

BE

So while revenue's a miss against consensus, considerably, the loan book's looking less of a basket case.

As it does every first quarter.

Does this justify 10% on STAN? Not to me it doesn't, but my opinion's irrelevant here.

Let me get some sellside.

11:11 am
BE

Ian Gordon at Investec walks us through the moving parts.

BE

U/L PBT fell by 64% YoY to $0.5bn (from $1.5bn in Q1 2015). The key issue (once again) was revenues, which fell 24% YoY to $3.3bn in Q1 2016, a 6% miss vs consensus ($3.57bn) and 2% below us ($3.40bn). With more limited cost take-out (-10% YoY) and elevated impairments of $0.6bn (+25% YoY/- 50% QoQ), u/l profits were crushed. However, restructuring spend (primarily impairments against discontinued businesses) was only $0.1bn in the quarter ($1.8bn in Q4 2015), and CET1 capital improved 50bps QoQ to 13.1%.

PM

Trader Gordon's a seller, no?

11:12 am
BE

He is, though on rejigged forecasts.

BE

Figure 1 overleaf illustrates the sharp decline in revenues over the past two years, with revenues declining by 24% YoY in Q1 2016. As expected, the primary area of weakness was in Corporate & Institutional where revenues of $1.8bn were down by $0.7bn (-27%). Retail also posted a significant decline, down $0.3bn (-19% YoY) to $1.2bn, albeit this was flat QoQ.

By product, there was broad-based weakness; Trade Finance (-28%), Retail Products (-21%), Corporate Finance (-20%) and Financial Markets (-19%).

Costs declined by $0.3bn (-10% YoY) to $2.2bn. Regulatory costs still represent a material and de facto “uncontrollable” element of STAN’s cost base, contributing to the wide negative jaws.

Impairments remained elevated at $0.6bn (c.90bps), but this represented a 50% QoQ improvement. The YoY increase was $0.1bn (+25%)

More positively, the CET1 capital ratio improved by 0.5% QoQ to 13.1%, primarily reflecting further balance sheet contraction during the quarter. Customer loans fell by $3.5bn (-5% annualised) to $265bn as ongoing de-risking actions continued and weak demand for credit persisted.

The outlook statement (unsurprisingly) expects “Group performance to remain subdued in 2016”. On 0.6x 2015-18e tNAV, Sell rec reaffirmed. Our 445p TP and the finer detail of our existing forecasts are now under review.

PM

Ah yes, under review

BE

BE

Standard Chartered reported better-than-expected Q1 PBT of $589m (JPMe
-$500m) with sequential stabilization in revenues which are +3% q/q,
despite loans -1% q/q (-2% relative to JPMe), good cost control (6% better
than JPMe) and lower-than-expected impairment, which halved to $0.6bn
from $1.2bn in Q4’15. CT1 build is the key highlight from the quarter,
improving to 13.1% (vs JPMe 12.8%) up 50bps q/q driven by decline in
RWAs and a return to profitability. Management indicates that it is taking
action to improve recent income trends and managing costs under tight
control. With capital continuing to improve, our thesis remains that the group
can continue its sequential improvement in revenues through 2016.

BE

Ditto Citi.

BE

1Q16 results (both profits and capital) are reassuring even if helped by seasonality (1Q usually a low provision accrual quarter for wholesale banking). There should be a positive read-across to HSBC GBM Asia and a negative across for Wealth Management/Retail.

Q: How would we expect investors to react?

A: Positively. Income was up QoQ, loan losses much lower than feared, and cost
reduction plans on target. The key question for the conference call, in our view, is on
the sustainability of low loan losses from a short quarter. The key issue for investors is
how much to pay for 2018 forecast earnings given a 44% rally in the share from its
YTD lows.

PM

(goldenoldie and others -- the thing about the pension deficit that no one seems to mention is that the assumptions got rejigged when it moved out of Green's control, cos it no longer had a well capitalised parent company. Green did not somehow steal the money. The man is not a fraud or a thief, to be clear.)

11:17 am
PM

Stan Chart (STAN LN, 550p, Buy, FV 645p) 1Q16 PTP of $539m is significantly better than our expectations of a loss of $235m, driven by much lower costs and impairments than our and market expectations. While revenues of $3.35bn were down 24% YoY (consensus down 20%), currency translation accounted for 3% YoY income decline and business divestments represented a further 2%. Total operating expenses were down 10% YoY (6% ex. Currency effects) to $2.2bn. CET1 ratio of 13.1% was also c.40bp better than our expectations. Overall, while the bears will focus on weak revenues, we continue to believe that consensus is too pessimistic on credit quality and impairment forecasts and these results prove that. At 2016E P/TBV of 0.6x and ROE expected to improve to

8% over the next few years, we continue to believe that Stan Chart is significantly undervalued especially considering its exposure to growth markets.

Capital – CET1 improved by 50bp QoQ to 13.1% (Haitong 12.7%) driven by higher profitability and RWAs falling by 3% to $295bn. Loans were down 1% QoQ reflecting reduced client asset demand and high levels of liquidity across our markets.

Credit Quality – Impairments of $471m were in the ongoing business with the liquidation portfolio only showing a $107m increase in provisions. Coverage ratio remained constant at 53%.

Outlook - ‘Given the ongoing challenging market conditions and the early implementation of our strategy, we expect Group performance to remain subdued in 2016. We continue to see opportunities with our clients and we are investing in areas of competitive strength. The fundamental value of the Group remains intact, and we are executing our strategy with discipline to drive the right type of business that will deliver sustainably higher returns over time.’

PM

Shailesh Raikundlia the analyst there

BE

Here's Barclays' bullet points.

11:22 am
BE

· Dividend unchanged at 10c/sh flat q/q.

· BP now expects to be free cash flow breakeven after dividends at $50-55/bl by 2017 versus previous guidance of $60/bl.

· BP’s cash costs over the last four quarters were $4.6bn lower than in 2014 and are on track to be $7bn lower in 2017 versus previous guidance of ‘close to’ $7bn.

· Adjusted EBIT of $994m was materially above consensus of $160m driven mainly by a better than expected downstream result which posted an operating profit of $1.8bn versus consensus of $1.1bn.

· The downstream beat appears to be mainly driven by the combination of a better result from trading and lower costs, but did reflect a strong performance across all business units.

· Downstream volumes expected to be lower q/q in 2Q given the impact of a significantly higher level of turnaround activity.

· Upstream production of 2,428kboe/d is up 5% y/y, compares with full year guidance of broadly flat production y/y and was 4% higher than our estimate.

· The upstream business lost money broadly in-line with consensus given the impact of weaker realizations and a small y/y increase of the exploration expense.

· 2Q upstream production is expected to be lower q/q.

· Underlying operating cash flow for 1Q was $3bn is up 20% y/y.

· $1bn of non-operating post tax charges in 1Q relating to Macondo costs and restructuring items.

· Organic capex to be $17bn this year versus previous guidance at the lower end of $17-19bn.

· Net debt to capital at the end of 1Q of 23.6% up 2pp q/q. To allow more flexibility in the current price environment BP will revert to targeting a net debt ratio of 20-30%.

CEO Bob Dudley: “Despite the challenging environment, we are driving towards our near-term goal of rebalancing BP’s cash flows. Operational performance is strong and our work to reset costs has considerable momentum and is delivering results. Furthermore, development of our next wave of material upstream projects is well on track.”

BE

And RBC.

BE

BP reported its first quarter results this morning with a bottom line beat on what were likely very low expectations with oil prices averaging
$33/bbl in the quarter. BP reported adj net income of $532m vs consensus -$140m. The beat appears primarily driven by the downstream, and
despite refining margins tracking down qoq in BP's key areas (e.g. US Mid-Continent), it appears the result was positively impacted by better
availability, lower costs and importantly a better trading result (vs 4Q15), which remains volatile and difficult to forecast. In terms of guidance, BP
has refined its capex guidance to $17bn for 2016, (consensus $16.9bn) whilst also indicating willingness to reduce it to $15-17bn in 2017 should
conditions warrant.
Upstream: The division remains loss making, and with broadly in line volumes, BP generated a loss of $747m in the quarter (RBCe -$300m, consensus -
$855m). This is despite slightly better volumes than we had forecast, with BP producing 2,428kboed (RBCe 2,356kboed). At the same time, as the chart below
highlights, cost reduction continues at BP, and on the two key income statement lines we track, costs were down 13% yoy (11% qoq).
Downstream: The downstream division was buoyed by a strong fuels segment which we found surprising, as this is typically the area most sensitive to refining
margins. BP note a strong trading performance relative to last quarter, which can typically be volatile. As a result, downstream earnings were $1,813m,
significantly higher than expectations (RBCe $900m, consensus $1,120m).
Capex, gearing, dividends: BP has refined its capex guidance to $17bn in 2016, whilst also indicating willingness to lower spending to $15-17bn in 2017
should conditions warrant. Gearing increased from 21.6% to 23.6% qoq. Dividends are unchanged at $0.10/quarter.
Outlook:
l 2Q production is expected to be lower qoq, reflecting PSA adjustments and seasonal turnarounds and maintenance activity.
l In the downstream, turnaround activity is expected to be "significantly higher" in 2Q, particularly in the US. BP expects some seasonal improvement in
refining margins.

PM

Like Cobham

Cobham PLC (COB:LSE): Last: 172.30, down 42.9 (-19.93%), High: 175.40, Low: 169.40, Volume: 6.76m
11:26 am
BE

Yeah, emergency rights issue too.

PM

Oh dear

BE

It's all rather self inflicted as well.

11:27 am
PM

You'd think that with all the upset in the world, Cobham would be doing just fine

BE

There's an issue with Australian ops but beyond that it's mostly management making a fist of things.

BE

Having previously levered up the business to about 3.5 times.

11:28 am
BE

I think it's fair to say that Cobham's a bit of a mess right now.

BE

Here's RBC to walk us through it.

BE

Profit cut: Trading profit was £15m in 1Q16 versus £50m in the prior year period, and the company noted there were three principal reasons for this
slow start to the year: (1) operational issues in the Wireless business resulting in delayed shipments and a one-off charge of £9m (which appear to
relate to internal problems/operational issues, and the company has made changes to management and strengthened internal controls), (2)
increasing headwinds in the commercial fly-in fly-out business (softer demand for natural resources customers in Australia); and (3) cost increases on
a small number of development programs in the Advanced Electronics Solutions Sector. The company said that the remainder of the Group continues
to trade in line with the Board’s expectations, with the order book slightly ahead of the year end position on a like-for-like basis.
De-leveraging actions: Due to the slow start to the year, higher investment in development programs than planned, and that 90% of debt is in US
dollars, the company has not been able to lever down post the Aeroflex acquisition as planned - was at 2.9x at end of 2015 versus 2.1x target, and
without any actions it would be approaching 3.5x in June 2016, the next covenant testing date. The £500m rights issue should help deleverage by
roughly a turn, by our estimates. The company also said it would maintain its £126m cash dividend, and would look to maintain dividend policy going
forward.
Cost reduction actions: Cobham said it was taking steps to reduce costs, and thinks it can target £30m annually, with £10m being delivered in 2016. The
company said the savings would come from a combination of restructuring, manufacturing outsourcing and overhead reduction activities across the
Group. It said the related costs “will be recognised largely in Cobham’s underlying trading profit, with no additional non-underlying charges
anticipated”.
Our View: Besides the headline 5% cut and equity raise, this morning’s release raises concerns regarding execution, which may take a while to
rebuild. The conference call this morning will be management’s first start to do this.

11:29 am
BE

Remember those Meggitt-Cobham merger rumours last year?

BE

BE

And then Meggitt ended up buying Cobham's composites business, leaving no-one happy?

yep

PM

PM

11:31 am
PM

Madness

PM

BE

(@FJP: not sure, but I think that sounds plausible.)

11:32 am
BE

Yeah, I don't understand the divi thing at all.

BE

Here's Sandy Morris at Jefferies, who's always readable.

BE

We could not envisage a scenario where Cobham risked breaching the net
debt/EBITDA covenant limit of 3.5x, but the operational issues at Wireless have
derailed our arithmetic. The scale of the problem is one thing, the scale of the
solution another. There is much to digest, but we firmly counsel against overreacting.
Close to the wind. At end FY15, net debt was £1,207m at an exchange rate of US$1.47/£.
At US$1.4475/£, Cobham faced another net debt translation headwind in FY16, probably in
the region £20-25m, in our view. We estimate a minimum EBITDA of around £360m (versus £396m for FY15) for the 12 months ending June 2016 was necessary to ensure net debt/ EBITDA remained below 3.5x. We could envisage a slightly uncomfortable situation at end
1H16, but a more satisfactory situation at end FY16. Then, we expected Cobham’s usually
strong cash generation to return net debt/EBITDA to around 2.5x over three to four years.
Our arithmetic has been de-railed by a number of issues, but primarily the operational issues at Cobham Wireless, including a one-off charge of £9m that caused 1Q16 trading profit to fall from £50m to £15m.

11:33 am
BE

I'm guessing Jefferies is shop here. Let me check the disclosures.

BE

Disappointment and some dismay. Even leaving aside the Wireless operational issues,
we venture complying with the debt covenant at end 1H16 was going to be a bit too close
for comfort. We are all for fixing things properly, though a £500m rights issue – around
20% of market capitalisation - is tough medicine, in our view. We concede it must right
the ship financially and end speculation about a dividend cut; speculation that we sense
has weighed materially on the share price, but it also implies Cobham is committed to
heavy investment for longer than we expected. We also concede we knew the integration
of Aeroflex demanded investment as did the four aircraft for the AMSA programme. In the
absence of details today, we will assume a 2 for 7 rights issue (around 325m new shares) at
150p, although this would raise only £488m before expenses.
That’s settled. What is certain is that the rights issue definitely sorts out the balance sheet
issue. Having that much certainty is a good starting point, in our view. There may also be
some comfort in the guidance FY16 EBIT will be around £15m below previous expectations,
implying a satisfactory 2H16 outcome. For FY17, we forecast underlying EPS of 19.23p
(Bloomberg consensus 20.1p). In FY16, we figure there is around £155m (around US$225m)
of debt that matures, hence at this stage we pencil in an interest saving of £20m before
tax and hold all else equal (we do not factor in the further targeted cost savings of £30m).
When we re-work our EPS for the increased shares in issue, pro-forma FY17 EPS emerges at
around 16p. A PER of 13x generates a notional share price of around 208p. Assuming the
FY17 dividend payment is also £126m – as for FY15 – the dividend emerges around 8.6p
implying a yield of approximately 4.1% at 208p. We note the TERP is around 200p.
A cold front. Inevitably, we believe there is scope for consternation until the dust settles.
After that, the key thing is that we estimate 80%-85% of the Group – all bar Wireless Test
and the Australian Fly-In, Fly-Out operations - is staying the course. Order intake in FY15 and
1Q16 appears to have been satisfactory in the Defence/Security businesses and latterly even
in Cobham Wireless. We understand proof that Wireless has been fixed may be demanded.
On 30 March, 2016, Inmarsat formally launched Fleet Xpress, a development that may
now generate demand for Cobham SATCOM. Having misjudged things, we are bound
to advocate some caution today, but we believe fears of a dividend cut already weighed
significantly on Cobham and so counsel against over-reacting.

BE

Yep.

11:34 am
BE

Jefferies Hoare Govett a division of Jefferies International Limited acts as a corporate broker for Cobham Plc.

Smiths Group PLC (SMIN:LSE): Last: 1,131, down 1 (-0.09%), High: 1,150, Low: 1,130, Volume: 347.47k
BE

Here's page one.

11:37 am
BE

Renewed strategic focus: The new Smiths management team is focused on
growth vs. cost-cutting / possible break-up under the previous CEO. In this report,
we model the potential outcome of this renewed strategic focus and upgrade
Smiths to Outperform, raising our SOTP-based TP to 1275p.
■ Focus to include cash and asset turns: Initiatives to generate improved growth
include generating more cash from improving turns combined with investing
further in product development and greater commercial exploitation of Smiths
engineering IP. We use the Credit Suisse HOLT® framework to assess the impact
of increased asset efficiency alongside improving growth.
■ Benchmarking against the peer group: We have undertaken a detailed peer
analysis for all five of Smiths' divisions across asset turns, R&D to sales and
profitability for the last full financial year. Relative to peers, Smiths scores well on
profitability (second quartile) but less so on R&D to sales and asset turns (third
and fourth quartile, respectively).
■ Three valuation scenarios based on improved performance:
Scenario 1 assumes asset turns move up to the peer group average and
through-cycle organic growth is 4% (vs. c2% historically), but EBITDA margins
fall to 17.2% vs 17.6% in 2016E because of increased investment. Potential
upside to the current price is 8% (to 1242p).
Scenario 2 as before but EBITDA margins see moderate growth to 18.5%.
Potential upside to the current price is 13% to 1302p.
Scenario 3 is our bull case assuming through-cycle growth of 5.5%, asset turns
in the upper quartile of the peer group and EBITDA margins expand further to
19.2%. This yields a share price of 1568p, or 36% potential upside.
■ Upgrade to Outperform, 1275p TP: With potential upside across all our
scenarios, Smiths trading at a material discount to our SOTP (-15%) and Morpho
extending its position in Detection (and likely moving near term M&A focus to
portfolio clean-up through small selective disposals), we upgrade to Outperform.
Our increased forecasts assume the Morpho deal completes in Q1 2017.

11:42 am
BE

Yeah, I've tried to understand Carpetright many times and given up.

BE

Shore's had more patience, though they are buyers so .........

BE

Carpetright has today announced a trading update for the 12 weeks to 23rd April 2016, with like for like sales in the UK increasing by 0.7% against a comparative of 10.5% in FY2015. Whilst our own estimates factored in c1.0% growth in LFL, we believe trading may have been impacted by a challenging Easter period. We also note that management has outlined the market as, “increasingly competitive”. Management continue to focus on its store rationalisation programme domestically, with two stores closed during the 12 week period and Carpetright now operating 434 stores in the UK. However the business will extend its concept store trial as part of its refurbishment programme.

Trading in Europe was strong with LfL sales increasing by 1.9%, up 4.6% for the financial year in local currency. Momentum appears to be returning overseas with total sales up 10.7% (against a comparative of -12.6%) during Q4 in sterling terms.

Management has point to a full year gross margin regression of between 80 and 100 basis points, with the range tightening from the guidance provided earlier in the year of between 100 to 150 bps. Our forecasts had factored in c110bps, so a positive revision is likely to be reflected in changes we make to our estimates.

Most notably, full year profit guidance for the year remains unchanged; consequently we are comfortable with our profit before tax estimate of £17.5m. Our EPS expectation for the year of 19.3p per share also remains unchanged.

Based on our current forecasts and the yesterday’s close price, Carpetright trades on a PER of c20x and an EV/EBITDA of c8x, falling to c16x and c7x respectively based on our current forecasts. Our recommendation on the business remains unchanged, we reiterate our BUY stance.

11:43 am
BE

Cantor's Freddie George holds.

BE

· Sales were behind the curve but gross margin guidance was better than expected – Group sales were reported to have declined by 0.9%. In the UK, total sales in the twelve weeks to April 23rd declined by 2.9%, including LFL growth of +0.7% vs. CFE Research 1.5%. The company has improved gross margin guidance to a decline of 80bps to 100bps from 100bps and 150bps, which indicates to us that the company strategically decided to undertake less discounting in the period. In the Rest of Europe (Holland, Belgium and Republic of Ireland), LFL sales were reported to have increased by 1.9% vs. CFE Research 3.5% while total sales increased by 10.7% benefited from the strengthening of the euro vs. CFE Research +1.0%.

· FY16 forecasts retained but FY17 forecasts revised upwards – Following this update, we are maintaining our FY16 pre-tax profit forecast of £17.5m (EPS: 19.5p), which compares to company consensus of £17.3m. We are, however, reducing our FY17 pre-tax profit forecast to £21.5m from £22.7m (EPS to 23.9p from 25.2p).

· Operational gearing in the earnings has been overstated – Since Wilf Walsh’s appointment as Chief Executive in July 2014, the company has launched a number of initiatives over the last year. They include the offer of interest free credit and a broadening of the categories and a strengthening of the assortment to include a stronger more aspirational and contemporary range. More recently, it has started to test a new retail concept as from July 2015, the results of which we believe have been mixed. We are also concerned that analysts have overstated the operational gearing in the earnings and that consensus earnings for FY17 and FY18 are too high. The middle to low end of the market, we believe, will continue to be promotional while competition particularly from Martin Harris’ Tapi format is gaining traction (already has 40 stores and has plans to open a further 20+ stores in 2016) and housing related spending is likely to remain positive but subdued.

· The stock is still expensive – The stock, which has declined by almost 15% since the January trading update but more recently has recovered, is still one of the most highly rated ‘bricks and mortar’ retailers and is valued at a premium to peers such as Topps Tiles (TPT LN – HOLD – TP 160p) and Dunelm (DNLM LN – BUY – TP 1,100p). It is rated at 19.7x our FY16 forecasts declining to 16.1x in the following year. We continue to prefer United Carpets (UCP – BUY -17.5p) and Victoria Carpets (VCP – BUY – 1,750p).

ALLIED MINDS. Portfolio company raises $80m. Allied Minds announces that it has formed a new subsidiary, ABLS Capital, to help fund the lead optimisation phase of up to 10 new drug candidates that pass initial feasibility studies funded by ABLS. As a reminder, ABLS was created in 2014 as a joint venture with Bristol-Myers Squibb (BMS) (80% ALM: 20% BMS) in order to identify and perform pre-clinical development on up to 10 potential novel small molecule drugs, in certain key therapeutic areas. BMS is committed to funding $20m, i.e. 20% of the lead optimisation programme and then has an option to acquire the drug/co. for a pre-agreed combination of upfront milestones based on a multiple of invested capital and a royalty based on sales. We understand that BMS originated the venture back in 2014 to benefit from ALM's extensive network, ability to locate and license early stage assets and we view today's news of further committed investment as encouraging third party validation and highlights the progress made to date. The JV, ABLS, has licensed and initiated three projects/co.s so far (ABLS I (Fibrotic diseases, from Harvard), ABLS II (Prostate cancer, from Yale), ABLS III (Cancer, from NYU) and is currently performing feasibility studies at BMS's Biocon BMS Research Centre (BBRC) in India. In summary, ABLS Capital and BMS have committed a total of $100m to fund the lead optimisation phase of research for up to ten drugs, with the funding contributed by Woodford Investment Management ($40m), Invesco ($20m), BMS ($20m) and $20m from 'Allied Minds and others'. While this is an early stage programme, we believe that there could be significant potential upside and believe this novel arrangement utilises ALM's skills in IP commercialisation while reducing clinical and commercial risk by partnering with BMS. Positive news.

BE

Downgrade to Sell
From a 507p peak in April 2015, ADN is down ~40%. More recently, shares have bounced 42% from 217p on 20 January 2016. We see this reflecting too much optimism, too soon, and Downgrade to Sell with a new 265p TP. At more than 1 standard deviation above historical mean PE, valuation looks full.
More down than upside risk
We do raise forecasts today to reflect the recent EM equity rally. Our new 265p TP assumes +5% to 10% p.a. equity market returns, a return to equity net inflows FY18E, £50m cost saves FY17E and £20m FY18E. But using different assumptions gives a Bear-Bull range of 171p to 342p.

BE

Performance risk
Relative performance of Aberdeen EM Equity has recovered, but Global and APAC equities continue to underperform. We see persistent Global Equities underperformance driving continued net outflows near-term.

11:49 am
BE

Short covering
In recent weeks’, short interest has fallen, which together with EM equity mark-to-market, may explain the recent strong share price performance.
Limited Scope for Further Cost Saves
Aberdeen expects to achieve £50m cost savings, mostly in FY17E. It has also indicated further, unquantified savings for FY18E. We forecast £20m, as we see only limited scope for further savings.
Dividend Risk
We forecast 19.5p DPS, maintained flat despite lack of earnings cover. Any reversal in recent EM equity market recovery could put this at risk.
M&A Looks Challenging
With a lack of organic drivers for fund flow recovery, ADN may look to M&A instead. But with an uncovered dividend and limited net cash or surplus capital available, we see any deal as likely to require equity funding.
Next News: 3 May
Aberdeen reports 1H 16 on 3 May. We do not expect positive surprise. We forecast £161m PBT, 9.3p EPS and flat 7.5p DPS, with net outflows of -£8.0bn Q2, H1 -£17.1bn (annualized 12% opening AUM, vs. 10% FY14 and FY15).

And some Shore on Petra

PM

Q3 FY2016 production, full-year target bolstered by Kimberley tailings; prices seasonally firmer, rest of CY16 dependent on “continued supply control”. Q3 FY2016 saw strong production of 995.9kct, flattered by the addition of attributable production from the recently announced Kimberley tailings joint venture. Said acquisition has resulted in upwards-revised FY2016 full-year guidance of 3.6-3.65Mct (previously: 3.3-.4Mct). Production for the nine months to March 2016 was 2.63Mct, so it would seem to us that the full-year target is eminently achievable.

Petra today revealed that rough prices in Q3 FY2016 were c.3.5% up on H1 FY2016 like-for-like, due to an improvement in rough diamond market conditions. However, the company cautioned that January to April is “seasonally the strongest time of the year” de to midstream and downstream restocking after the core festive retail selling season, and that conditions during the rest of CY2016 would likely be dependent on “continued supply control from the major producers”.

Revenues for the quarter were impressive at US$120.5m, due to increased volumes and the US$15m sale of the 32.3ct pink diamond from Williamson. For comparison, H1 FY2016 revenue was US$154m. As of end Q3 FY2016, net debt was US$395.6m (Q2 FY2016: US$324.4m) while cash had decreased slightly, to US$39m (Q2 FY2016: US$41.6m). Undrawn, available debt facilities totalled US$114m.2m (Q2 FY2016: US$177.1m).

According to Petra, the expansion programmes at Finsch and Cullinan, and the construction of the new plant at Cullinan, are all on-track. The company is confident that its revised covenant and debt facility levels are “aligned to successfully complete” these programmes.

Petra's FQ3/16 production beat expectations by 20% on higher-than-forecast production from Kimberley Tailings. Sales of 938kcts were in line withforecasts but revenues of US$120M missed by 12% on a 14% lower-than-forecast diamond price, which was negatively impacted by the mix of productsold from Cullinan and Koffiefontein (which can be variable on a q/q basis). Together with the results, Petra announced that it has renegotiated the terms andstructure of its debt to provide greater headroom on its covenants. Petra expectsto pass through the July ‘16 to March ’17 peak funding period with a liquidityheadroom of US$70-100M.
Impact & Analysis
Mixed. Whilst revenue missed forecasts, the better-than-expected production is expected to flow through to sales in FQ4 and the mix of product sold is expectedto partially smooth out over the rest of the half. It is also encouraging to see thecontinued improvement in grades at Cullinan (up 10% q/q and 46% y/y) and Finsch which demonstrate the ramp up in production from undiluted ore. The impact of the Q3 results and slightly revised forecasts is that EBITDA is reduced to US$154M on the lower Q3 revenues with a knock-on reduction to FY16E earnings, which now stand at US$0.08/share (from US$0.10/share previously). Positively, Petra has also renegotiated the structure of its debt andthe covenants, in order to provide additional breathing space. The key covenantfrom our perspective is net debt to EBITDA; the limit has been increased from

So we don’t struggle to be positive about the growth opportunity that Nissin might
unlock. But what we are less positive around its ultimate size. We estimate Premier’s

Noodle culture is taking off in London, but we suspect that it’s less established
in Premier’s middle market heartlands. We also note that Nissin’s entire EMEA noodle sales
amount to only $40m, or less than 40% of Premier’s current business in the UK alone.
So while we get the growth story in noodles, we’re not yet convinced that the absolute
size of the opportunity is that material to Premier’s growth ambitions.
